The spleen was an intermediate organ that originally lined the gut wall. The first "forays" into terrestrial life led to both physical selection for pelvic development and higher exposure to nutritional iron. Darkness had little to do with it. Despite artistic renderings, the first breach of land occurred in shady wet areas where UV diffraction was inconsequential in shallow dwelling creatures. Abundant nutritional calcium led to rapid development of the pelvis and circulatory necessity led to hollow spaces that recruited splenic hematopoietic cells from the bloodstream. The spleen migrated because of the increasingly beneficial recruitment of abdominal musculature.

what I doubt about this theory is why bones like the skull, and the collarbones have red bone marrow... the skull is like 5mm thick overall, the skull's external layer is at most 2mm, and that's thick for what I've seen, the head is also one of the most exposed to sun body parts, just imagine, if a dim light like a flashlight can cross through a finger, sunlight can cross the skull, even more with bald people, I'm sure most light can, at least reach the diploe where red bone marrow is... and liver or kidneys are way more protected, also, both organs can produce blood cells at least in embryonal stages, there's no reason to switch that places if is because of sunlight.

if I had to give another reason, but that's just pure speculation, it should be infections, bones almost allways get infected because of severe wounds, and if an infection reaches them is usually diseases like tuberculosis or syphilis, which are extremely invasive... kidneys can get injured by pyelonephritis and the liver by hepatitis...

BTW they have strong evidence with fishes and amphibians... but is still weird in my opinion that more exposed bones are apparently more capable of preserve red bone marrow than other, better protected like the femur

Hey Hank, just a friendly reminder! Humans also begin prenatal haematopoiesis in our liver, spleen and other tissues, migrating production to the bones after the marrow develops, so I guess we have more in common with frogs than meets the eye haha. It’s also worth noting that these organs maintain the ability to resume blood production extramedulllary in certain conditions like chronic inflammation or disease, even during adulthood. Great videos, keep it up!

I was born with beta thalassemia major, a genetically inherited blood disorder that is caused due to a mutation of the beta globin gene, rendering it useless. People like me require frequent red blood cell transfusions to survive. I need 48 bags of blood in a single year 🛑

To know if you're a carrier of this gene mutation for not, please conduct the Hba2 blood test as soon as possible. Two people with minor traits have a high chance of producing an offspring with major traits, which leads to lifelong dependency on blood transfusions along with a whole list of other issues, many of which are fatal.

And the hormone telling your bones to make red blood cells comes from the kidney. That's something I learned because my partner's kidney is failing and it's not producing that hormone anymore.

Edit: Well, my partner technically has three kidneys. One of which is so small they think it never functioned to begin with. One of which failed on him a little over 10 years ago (he thought he had swine flu as it failed during that pandemic and he nearly died because he didn't go to the hospital until a concerned friend literally dragged him there). And the final kidney was the one he received from an organ donor a little less than 10 years ago - it just started to fail about two years ago. As the average donor kidney from a dead donor typically lasts about 8 years on average, he got pretty good mileage out of it. They're prepping him to go back on dialysis now and he's been put back on the kidney donor list. The doctors are actually surprised at how the kidney is still holding on - they expected him to be back on dialysis last summer, but the kidney's still hanging in there.

I wonder if there’s a connection between bones producing red blood cells and the fact that their production requires a lot of the vitamin folate. Turns out that the development of dark skin probably was more related to protecting folate, which gets destroyed by UV radiation., (and Not necessarily to prevent skin cancer).  Folate is absolutely necessary for rapid cell turnover (such as blood cells, sperm production, preventing spina bifida), and therefore essential for fertility (i.e., evolutionary fitness).

It took a bone disease for me to learn how the body repairs aging and broken bones. A broken bone  bleeds and forms a blood clot in the fracture. The body has processes that convert the clot into solid bone and some type of “cytes “ tunnel through the solid bone to create pathways for  new blood vessels . Bone is alive and needs a blood supply. Dying bone is a 24/7 pain that I couldn’t wish on anyone.

I’m not convinced by these explanations, and think this may be overly simplified ...for a couple reasons:
1. My understanding is that birds generally don’t have bone marrow (at least birds that fly), so how are they “pretty similar to us”? How is there blood made in their bones without marrow? and
2. More importantly, how is UV damage a concern below the level of the skin? I can’t imagine much UV radiation makes it more than a few millimeters below the skin’s surface, so why would blood making cells need to go so deep down into the bones to hide from UV?
I would appreciate anyone who can explain or dispute those issues. But I suspect there’s something else much more complicated going on that merely makes it look like it’s UV light driving this trait through natural selection (and we must always remember that “correlation does not imply causation”)
